By Sudip Roy

LONDON, Dec 7 (IFR) - Investors pour cash into trades

Latvia printed its debut sustainability bond on Monday, a €600m January 2030 offering that priced close to fair value.

The upsized deal, which was originally due to raise €500m, came at 25bp over swaps from IPTs of the low 30s as books swelled to more than €2.35bn.

Latvia is a well-regarded name and on the sovereign's previous visit to the market nearly six months ago, it also priced the €500m no-grow January 2029 bond close to fair value.

Latvia was one of three issuers in the European market on Monday - the international financing and leasing arm of Japan’s Nippon Telegraph and Telephone raised €1.5bn through a dual-tranche issue, while UK asset manager abrdn printed a sterling AT1. What was noticeable about all three trades was the strength of demand. NTT Finance, for example, saw combined books of more than €6.5bn. An ESG label - the bonds were issued under a green use-of-proceeds structure - may have played a part, as it may have done on Latvia's deal. But even so there were encouraging signs that investors have yet to shut up shop.

The US dollar market, meanwhile, was busy with eight issuers, including Banco de Chile, raising US$16bn. So although there are central bank meetings to navigate, Monday's deals might yet encourage one or two more issuers to try their hand before year-end.

Indeed, risk-on price action has extended across global markets overnight. Nominally it has come amid easing anxiety over the Omicron variant of Covid-19, although Treasuries erasing the excess exuberance after last Thursday’s superficially weak US employment report, and setting up for big duration supply over the rest of the week, has also played a role.

Ten-year Treasury futures are down a few ticks from their settle, but are down almost half a point from when Europe went home. S&P futures meanwhile are up more than 25 points or 0.6%, after the S&P 500 gained 1.2% yesterday.

Asian bourses show the Nikkei up 1.9%, and the CSI300 up 0.3%. The dollar has given back much of yesterday’s moderate gains, the index easing to DXY96.20, with the euro slightly stronger at EUR/USD1.1294. The yen in contrast is slightly weaker at USD/JPY113.71. Gold is a little higher at US$1,781.60, and Bitcoin continues to recover after Saturday’s sharp sell-off, up slightly to over US$51,000.00. Oil is also strong, Brent crude up US$0.84 at US$73.92.

Finally, Turkey’s lira remains steady below USD/TRY14.000, but still has not rallied from this level, and so remains poised to break weaker above last Thursday’s high of USD/TRY13.9000, and so presumably in short order last week’s high of USD/TRY14.0000, beyond which we can only guess at when it will eventually stabilize.

News from overnight saw the Reserve Bank of Australia leave policy unchanged, as had been expected, and come across with a neutral statement.
